proposals.reasoning: Given zero hard info, I’m prioritizing a low-conflict, informative start that the table broadly supports. Multiple players (Bob, Charlie, Diana, myself) expressed comfort with Alice + Eve, and no one strongly opposed it. Alice is generally a reliable early pick, and putting Eve—who tends to be quieter—on the first mission lets us get an immediate read on her alignment through the result and subsequent reactions, while keeping several vocal/meta players off the team to analyze from the outside. This balances mission success chances with maximizing early informational value.

votes.comment: Standard low-info opener, I’m on it and there’s broad soft consensus with no strong red flags yet.
Consistent with my earlier preference for Alice+Eve; low-info first mission but solid, and I’m fine staying off to watch reactions.
Reasonable low-info opening team with no known evil to me; aligns with table consensus and keeps discussion calm for now.
As evil I want my teammate Eve on early teams to give us flexibility to pass or fail and shape future suspicions.
I’m on the team and early participation gives me flexibility and information for later missions.
Fits my stated preference for Alice+Eve as a low-conflict, informative first mission with no strong objections raised.

discussion.content: With no info yet, I’d like to start as cleanly as possible: I’m fine with a simple, low-drama first team like me + one of Bob/Eve, and then we use the result to calibrate. If anyone has strong meta-reads from past games, now’s the time to speak up before we lock in.
I’m okay with you taking the lead here, Alice—between your suggested options I slightly prefer you + Eve, and I’d rather watch the first mission from the sidelines to get a feel for how people react.

Alice + Eve is a reasonable low-info start, especially since Bob seems happy to stay off and observe; I’d just avoid overloading the first team with the louder/meta-heavy players so we can learn more from the outside votes and reactions.

I’m okay with Alice starting us off, and between the options I slightly lean Alice + Eve just so we get an early read on how the table reacts to Eve being on the first mission. That said, if people are nervous about that, Alice + Bob is a fine low-stress alternative.

I’m fine being on the first team, but I slightly prefer Alice + Bob to start just because both of you tend to play pretty straightforwardly and give us a cleaner baseline read. If the table’s already leaning Alice + Eve though, I won’t fight it hard.

I’m okay with Alice on pretty much any first team, and between the options I slightly prefer Alice + Eve so we get an early read on someone who’s usually quieter, while keeping the more vocal/meta players (Bob/Charlie) outside to judge reactions.

proposals.reasoning: I know I’m good, so I want myself on the mission. Mission 1 (Alice + Eve) was clean, which slightly soft-clears Eve but doesn’t confirm her, so I’d like to widen information rather than just repeat almost the same team. Bob is a broadly supported low-drama addition that several people have suggested testing early, and Charlie is another player multiple people have mentioned as a good info pick. Running Alice–Bob–Charlie gives us two fresh alignments compared to Mission 1 while keeping at least one member from the prior successful team (me), which balances safety with gaining new information about Bob and Charlie for future missions.

votes.comment: I trust myself, Mission 1 went clean with me on it, and this team efficiently tests both Bob and Charlie while keeping a proven configuration structure. It’s a reasonable info-gathering lineup for Quest 2.
Good info team: I know I’m good, Alice came from a clean M1, and testing Charlie early is valuable even though there’s some risk he’s evil.
Fits the agreed structure (one of Alice/Eve plus Bob, with me added), excludes any obvious risk and should give good info with a solid chance of success.
Fits the ‘keep one of Alice/Eve and add Bob’ info plan we discussed, and adding Charlie widens our reads without feeling overly risky for Mission 2.
Too many unknowns and no overlap with me or Mission 1’s full lineup; I’d prefer at least one of Eve/Alice plus someone I have a stronger read on before giving good a potential second clean success.

I prefer having myself (the previous leader) or Eve from the clean Mission 1 on this team rather than running two completely untested players together, and the stated reasoning doesn’t match the actual proposed lineup.

discussion.content: Mission 1 going clean with me and Eve is a decent early sign, so I’d like to keep at least one of us on the next team and add someone who felt naturally engaged and not overly careful in their reactions—right now I’m leaning toward including Bob unless something major changes.

I like keeping at least one of Alice/Eve from the clean first mission, and I’m fine being the third if you want, but I’d also be interested in seeing someone like Charlie tested early if you’re unsure about me.

I like keeping one of Alice/Eve from the clean mission and adding Bob as a low-drama test, rather than widening to people we know nothing about yet. That gives us some new info without overexposing the team this early.

I like the idea of keeping exactly one of Alice/Eve from the clean mission and adding Bob for a low-variance test, since that gives us new info without throwing three mostly-untested people together. Alice/Eve + Bob feels like a solid, reasonable lineup for Mission 2.
I’m on board with the “one of Alice/me plus Bob” idea, and I’m fine sitting this one out if people prefer Alice–Bob–Charlie as a lower-drama info team.

I like the “exactly one of Alice/Eve plus Bob” structure, and given Mission 1 was clean with Alice and Eve, I’d lean Alice–Bob–Charlie here so we get fresh info on both Bob and Charlie without overcomplicating things.

proposals.reasoning: We have two clean missions so far: Mission 1 with [Alice, Eve] and Mission 2 with [Alice, Bob, Charlie]. The overlap strongly suggests that at least Alice plus most of that group are good, and there’s no evidence yet to justify swapping in an untested player on a potential win mission. Including [Alice, Bob, Charlie] again preserves the fully successful core from Mission 2, and adding Eve uses the only other player who has already been on a clean mission rather than introducing extra variance with both Diana and Frank still untested. This team maximizes our chance of a 3–0 lock while leaving Mission 4 available, if needed, to more deliberately test between the remaining players.

votes.comment: Both prior missions with subsets of this team were clean; on a potential win mission it’s correct to run back the proven core plus the only other previously clean player rather than introduce new variance.
Low-variance potential win: reusing the fully clean [Alice, Bob, Charlie] core and adding the only other player from a clean mission (Eve) is the safest option right now.
Consistent with two prior clean missions and my stated preference to reuse the [Alice, Bob, Charlie] core with Eve as the lowest-variance fourth on a potential win mission.
Team reuses the only fully clean core and adds the only other player with a successful history; avoiding untested slots on a potential win mission makes sense.
Includes the proven 3p core plus me from a prior success; lowest-variance path on a potential win mission.
Lowest-variance team using only players from prior clean missions; no evidence yet to justify introducing an untested player on a potential win mission.

discussion.content: Given we’re 2-for-2 with [Alice, Eve] and then [Alice, Bob, Charlie], I really want at least Alice + Bob + Charlie back on this team and then we can debate whether Eve or one of Diana/Frank is the safer fourth.

I’m good keeping the [Alice, Bob, Charlie] core since it’s 2-for-2, and right now I slightly prefer adding Eve as the fourth just because she’s the only other person with a clean track record. If we’re nervous about repeating, we could at least agree that exactly one of Diana/Frank max should touch a team until we see more.

I’m happy reusing the [Alice, Bob, Charlie] core for now, and between the options I slightly prefer adding Eve as the fourth since she’s the only other person who’s actually been on a clean mission. I’d rather not jump straight into testing Diana/Frank when we don’t have to risk two untested slots at once.

I agree the [Alice, Bob, Charlie] core looks as safe as we’re going to get right now, but I’m a little wary of auto-locking Eve as “clean” off one 2p success. I’d rather use this mission to actually test one of me/Frank alongside that core instead of just repeating the only other person who’s been on a team.

I’m fine sticking with the [Alice, Bob, Charlie] core and adding me as the fourth since it’s the lowest-variance option right now, and we can always use Mission 4 to more cleanly test Diana/Frank if this stays green.

Given we’re on a potential win mission, I’d rather lock in the lowest-variance team, so I’m on board with [Alice, Bob, Charlie, Eve] here and we can use Mission 4 to properly test between me and Diana if needed.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice/Bob/Charlie was clean, and the only change that produced the single fail on Mission 3 was adding Eve. With no evidence of multiple evils hiding in the Mission 2 team and given the 2–1 score, the most information-consistent and safest play is to revert to the last proven-successful trio rather than introduce new variables on a critical mission.

votes.comment: Mission 2 with this exact trio was clean, Mission 3 only failed when Eve was added, and the strongest structural read is that the single fail came from the new addition rather than from someone in the previously clean team.

Mission 2 with Alice/Bob/Charlie was clean; the only change that produced a fail was adding Eve. Given Charlie’s strong support here and my Percival read, reverting to the last successful trio is the most consistent and likely-good team.
Mission 2’s Alice/Bob/Charlie was clean, and the only change that produced a fail on Mission 3 was adding Eve; reverting to the last proven-successful trio is structurally the safest line here.

Reverting to Mission 2 assumes there wasn’t already an evil in that trio using Eve as cover on Mission 3; if that assumption is wrong, we’re handing a likely hidden evil a critical mission uncontested. I’d rather see at least one swap to avoid auto-locking all three again.

If an evil was already on the Mission 2 team, reverting to Alice/Bob/Charlie just locks that hidden evil into a must-pass mission; we should at least consider a small swap instead of auto-trusting the trio.

If an evil was already in Alice/Bob/Charlie, Mission 3 is perfect cover to blame Eve. Keeping all three together again risks locking in a hidden evil on a critical mission; I want at least one swap (including me or Diana).

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2’s team of Alice/Bob/Charlie is our cleanest data point, but Mission 3 showed that keeping all three of them together isn’t guaranteed safe—either Eve is the lone variable, or an evil on that team used her as cover. To avoid hard-locking the entire Mission 2 trio while still leveraging the strongest prior trust, I’m keeping the two most structurally trusted members (Alice and Bob, who have both been on only successful missions when not paired with Eve) and swapping out Charlie for me. This respects the logic of reverting toward Mission 2 while addressing the concern Frank and I raised about potentially entrenching a hidden evil if one of the original three isn’t actually clean.

votes.comment: From my perspective, reverting to the fully tested Mission 2 team (Alice/Bob/Charlie) is structurally stronger. This team introduces Diana while still keeping Bob, who might be the hidden evil from the earlier clean mission using Eve as cover on Mission 3. I’d rather push back toward ABC than add an untested variable here.

Given my Percival info, I’m more inclined to see Charlie as the real Merlin and Diana as likely Morgana. If Diana is evil, this ABD team can easily be double-evil with Alice+Diana, which would lose us the game. ABC is still the structurally safest all-good candidate from my perspective.

I still think reverting fully to the clean Mission 2 team (Alice/Bob/me) is the most consistent with the info we have; swapping in an untested player here just to break up that trio feels like adding uncertainty on a critical mission.
This leverages the proven-safe core from Mission 2 while avoiding the risk of locking in the full Alice/Bob/Charlie trio again; I’m comfortable testing this slight variation.

Swapping out previously clean Charlie for untested Diana feels like ignoring our strongest info; if we’re moving off Mission 2, I’d rather see a team that either keeps Charlie or meaningfully rebalances, not just plug in a new wildcard.

Given the mission history, the only consistent evil pairing that makes Alice/Bob/Diana all good is {Charlie, Eve}; in all other plausible worlds at least one of Alice, Bob, or Diana is evil, so this team is too likely to contain evil.

proposals.reasoning: Structurally, we learn and protect ourselves best by not auto-locking the entire Mission 2 trio again while still anchoring the team on someone everyone broadly trusts. Alice has been on both successful missions, so she’s our stability piece. The main debate now is whether we keep all of Alice/Bob/Charlie together or acknowledge the risk Diana flagged: if an evil was already sitting in that block, Mission 3 was the perfect time to use me as cover. This team breaks that cluster but doesn’t go full chaos—just a controlled swap of Bob/Charlie out for Diana while keeping Alice. Including me forces us to actually test the “Eve is the only variable” assumption instead of just treating it as solved; if I’m bad, this team will out me, and if I’m good, we stop hard-tunneling the same trio and open up the real hidden evil. Frank specifically asked for a team that doesn’t just keep all three of Alice/Bob/Charlie together and that brings in at least one of him or Diana; this satisfies that structural concern while still keeping one of the most trusted players (Alice) on the mission.

votes.comment: Best structural read is still that Eve is the likeliest source of the single fail on Mission 3; this team keeps the main suspect on a critical mission instead of reverting to the previously clean Alice/Bob/Charlie trio.
Eve is still the likeliest source of the Mission 3 fail; I don’t want her on a critical team when we have the cleaner Mission 2 block to work from.

This keeps Alice, who’s broadly trusted, but swaps in Diana while still keeping Eve—the prime suspect from the M2→M3 change. Putting our main suspect plus an unproven swap on a critical mission is too risky.
This breaks up the potentially contaminated Alice/Bob/Charlie block while still keeping a trusted anchor in Alice and adds me for fresh info, which fits the structural concerns raised.

This fits the structural concern of not auto-locking the Mission 2 trio while still keeping Alice as an anchor, and it directly tests the assumption that I was the sole new variable causing Mission 3 to fail.
Given mission results, any consistent evil placement makes this team contain at least one evil (Eve and/or Diana, possibly Alice), so it’s never fully clean.

proposals.reasoning: Reverting to Alice/Bob/Charlie hard-locks us into the exact trio that an embedded evil would want to protect, using Eve as a convenient scapegoat for Mission 3’s single fail. Structurally, many 3-person teams have the same raw odds of being clean, so the deciding factor should be social information and mission overlap. This team keeps Alice, who has been central on the two clean missions, but breaks up the Bob/Charlie block that is strongly incentivized to push a revert. Adding Diana and myself brings in two players who have never been on a failing mission together and avoids grouping all three of Alice/Bob/Charlie again, reducing the risk that we’re blindly locking in a hidden evil while still preserving key prior successes.

votes.comment: The clean-to-fail change from Mission 2 to 3 still most strongly implicates Eve, and Frank has been tightly aligned with Eve’s narrative. The Eve+Frank spy world fits the proposal-voting patterns well, which would make this team (Alice/Diana/Frank) likely to contain 1 evil. I prefer reverting to the proven Mission 2 team of Alice/Bob/Charlie.

Mission 2’s Alice/Bob/Charlie is our only fully clean data point; the only change on the failed Mission 3 was adding Eve, so excluding both me and Charlie here needlessly abandons the safest-known core for a riskier, less-proven mix.
Puts an unknown pair of Diana/Frank on a must-pass mission while breaking up a previously successful Bob/Charlie structure; feels like unnecessary reshuffling this late.

This keeps Alice from the clean missions but breaks up the Bob/Charlie block that could be hiding an embedded evil using Eve as cover for Mission 3, and it brings in two players (me and Frank) who haven’t been on a failed team together.

This breaks up the Bob/Charlie block I was worried about while keeping Alice from the clean missions, and it avoids auto-locking back into the exact trio that could be hiding an embedded evil using me as scapegoat.

Best compromise that breaks up the Bob/Charlie block while keeping only one of the highly central players and adding two players (me and Diana) who have never been on a failing mission together; fits my earlier stance against auto-reverting to Alice/Bob/Charlie.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice, Bob, and Charlie succeeded with 0 FAILs. The only change going into Mission 3 was adding Eve, which introduced exactly 1 FAIL. The simplest and most information-consistent explanation is that Eve is the evil added on Mission 3, while the Mission 2 trio is all good. Alternative worlds where an evil in Alice/Bob/Charlie waited until Mission 3 to fail are possible but require extra assumptions about coordination and timing, and both Eve and Frank are notably pushing to break up this proven-success trio, which aligns with an evil incentive to avoid being cleanly excluded. Reverting to the Mission 2 team most likely gives us a fully good team for this critical mission.

discussion.content: Given that the only change from the clean mission 2 to the failed mission 3 was adding Eve, I’m most comfortable reverting to the mission 2 team of me, Bob, and Charlie here.

Reverting to the Mission 2 team makes the most sense to me—Eve is the only new variable between a clean and a failed mission. I’m happy with Alice/Bob/Charlie here unless someone has a really compelling alternative world where the fail didn’t come from Eve.

Going back to the Mission 2 team seems like the most information-consistent option: same three people, clean result, and the only change that produced a fail was adding Eve. I’m good with Alice/Bob/Charlie here unless someone sees a realistic world where one of them slipped a fail on Mission 3 instead of pinning it on the Eve swap.

On pure structure, reverting to the Mission 2 team does look best, since Eve is the only new variable between clean and fail. The only thing I’d flag is that if we’re wrong and one of Alice/Bob/Charlie used the cover of “blame the new person,” we’re locking a hidden evil into a critical mission.

I get why everyone’s defaulting to blaming me, but if an evil was already sitting in the Mission 2 team, Mission 3 is exactly when they’d use “Eve is new” as perfect cover for a single fail. I’d rather see at least one swap from Alice/Bob/Charlie—something like Alice/Charlie/me or Bob/Charlie/Diana—than just blindly lock back in Mission 2.

I’m really not sold on auto-locking Alice/Bob/Charlie—Mission 3 is exactly when an evil in that trio would use Eve as cover—so I’d rather see a team that includes at least one of me or Diana and doesn’t keep all three of them together.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning Merlin = Alice: she naturally took the lead in shaping every “correct” team, kept the core of [Alice, Bob, Charlie] together once it was proving clean, and immediately snapped to the Eve-as-sole-new-variable explanation after the Mission 3 fail. Bob and Charlie both look good and logical, but they felt more like they were following Alice’s framing than subtly steering it themselves.

I’m with Diana that Alice is the best Merlin candidate: she consistently framed the “right” worldview early (pushing clean, low-variance teams that happened to be good), and both Bob and Charlie mostly slotted into her logic instead of independently driving it. Her instant, confident pivot to “Eve is the only new variable, so she’s the fail” after Mission 3 feels more like someone with extra info locking in the correct blame than a regular good player nervously guessing.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Alice consistently drove the correct team structures from the start, anchoring on low-variance lineups that just happened to be fully good and then preserving the clean [Alice, Bob, Charlie] core once it proved successful. After Mission 3 failed, she immediately and confidently locked onto Eve as the unique new variable and source of the fail, which fits someone with extra information more than a normal good player who should still be considering worlds where the fail came from inside the original trio.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy on missions and helped establish a solid core by supporting the same successful team compositions, which contributed to securing three clean mission successes. I could improve by being more vocal in publicly challenging the narrative after the Mission 3 fail, as I relied a bit too much on quiet consistency rather than actively shaping the table’s suspicions.

player_observations.Bob: Played very much like a coordination anchor, repeatedly backing stable teams and projecting a calm, logical good-aligned vibe, which fit his Percival role well. He seemed to carefully avoid over-clearing anyone, which probably helped keep Merlin safer.
player_observations.Charlie: Subtly guided team selections without drawing too much attention, giving just enough resistance at key moments to steer us away from worse lineups. His balance of influence and restraint was very Merlin-like in hindsight, but in real time it was just quiet, credible leadership.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed relatively low-impact this game, which made her harder to pin as evil and kept suspicion from focusing on her. Her lack of strong pushes likely helped her Morgana role avoid being heavily scrutinized.
player_observations.Eve: Managed to blend in early by participating in a clean Mission 1 and then joining the mixed Mission 3 where the fail occurred, which created confusion about where the evil came from. She felt opportunistic in team votes, often okay with ambiguous lineups that preserved doubt.
player_observations.Frank: Set a trustworthy tone by leading a clean first mission and then not over-asserting himself afterward, which made him read very consistently good. His straightforward play and willingness to stick with proven teams helped reinforce the good bloc’s credibility.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated pretty well with Charlie once I suspected he was Merlin, especially by backing his team suggestions on Missions 2 and 4 and not over-explaining why I trusted him. I could improve by pushing harder after Mission 3’s fail to frame the suspicion more clearly on Diana/Eve instead of letting the evil team keep the pool of suspects too wide. I also should have left a few more intentional "false trails" about who I thought Merlin was so the assassin had a harder time locking in on Alice.

player_observations.Alice: Took leadership confidently and proposed mostly safe, information-light teams that still moved the game forward, especially on Missions 2 and 4. Her calm play and low-reactivity under suspicion made her look like a strong Merlin candidate, which clearly influenced the assassin’s choice.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled, subtle Merlin game—giving just enough guidance on teams without over-asserting or hard-clearing people, especially around Missions 2 and 4. His restraint after the Mission 3 fail (not tunnel-accusing anyone) helped him blend in and avoid the assassin’s attention.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed relatively quiet and opportunistic, letting others drive team discussions while she adjusted her stance to keep options open. Her low profile helped evil avoid early detection, but it also meant she didn’t create strong alternative narratives that could have pulled suspicion further away from Eve.
player_observations.Eve: Managed to look cooperative early by passing Mission 1 and joining the failing Mission 3 in a way that didn’t immediately single her out. She balanced participation and ambiguity well, but the pattern of safe teams plus that one fail eventually put her in a narrower suspect pool among attentive players.
player_observations.Frank: Opened the game with a simple, low-risk Mission 1 that didn’t generate much information but also didn’t raise suspicion on himself. He generally followed the emerging consensus on reads, playing a straightforward good-game that supported trust-building without overcomplicating the table talk.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I managed my Merlin info fairly well, subtly steering toward the correct teams on Missions 1, 2, and 4 without drawing too much suspicion, as shown by the assassin choosing Alice instead of me. I could improve by seeding clearer doubt on Mission 3’s failing team earlier and by giving Percival (Bob) slightly stronger, but still deniable, signals so evil had a harder time narrowing down Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Played very solid, trustworthy good—her consistent inclusion on successful teams made her look like a safe core, which also helped shield me as Merlin when she was assassin’s guess.
player_observations.Bob: Classic Percival behavior: strongly anchored around the Alice/Charlie pair and defended those teams; he played cautiously but clearly tried to lock in a Merlin candidate without over-arguing.
player_observations.Diana: Subtle Morgana presence—she didn’t over-push bad teams, instead letting others propose while she blended in and relied on ambiguity around the Merlin/percival pair.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, she took calculated risks, joining the successful Mission 1 to build credibility and then participating in the single fail on Mission 3 without becoming the obvious scapegoat.
player_observations.Frank: Played like a straightforward, information-light good—quiet but cooperative; his early trust in the Alice/Eve team on Mission 1 gave evil a bit of cover but also didn’t create major suspicion on him.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively consistent with my voting and didn’t attract much suspicion early, which helped evil get Mission 3 to fail. However, I didn’t do enough to frame Alice as Merlin convincingly, and I underestimated how well Charlie hid, leading to a wrong assassination.

player_observations.Alice: Played very clean and trustworthy, especially as a frequent leader, and managed to avoid looking like Merlin despite being central to multiple successful missions.
player_observations.Bob: Classic Percival behavior: strongly anchored on a Merlin read and protected it, supporting stable teams and not overreacting to the single fail on Mission 3.
player_observations.Charlie: Excellent Merlin play—gave just enough subtle direction to keep good on track without appearing overly controlling, and avoided the spotlight even after the failed Mission 3.
player_observations.Eve: Took a low-profile approach as Mordred, blending in well with early mission successes and not pushing too hard, which made it difficult to pin the fail on them later.
player_observations.Frank: As an early leader, set a calm tone with a safe Mission 1 and then largely followed emerging consensus, contributing to good’s cohesion by not introducing unnecessary chaos.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the Mission 3 fail without drawing too much suspicion directly onto myself, and I stayed reasonably consistent with my earlier voting and table talk. I should have pushed much harder to frame Bob as Merlin instead of Alice and paid more attention to Charlie’s subtle but accurate nudges on team selection that I underweighted in the assassination.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforward and confidently, which made her look like a solid generic good rather than a power role, especially since she kept choosing the same core team without overexplaining.
player_observations.Bob: Behaved like a classic Percival, visibly protecting Alice and Charlie with mild but consistent support while avoiding bold Merlin-like reads, which should have been a bigger red flag.
player_observations.Charlie: Very controlled and precise with their influence on teams—especially in supporting the successful 2nd and 4th missions—subtly steering outcomes without making loud accusations.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, her alignment with my reads was a bit too close at times, which risked linking us together; she played aggressively but could have diversified her stated suspicions more.
player_observations.Frank: Early mission leader who seemed cautious and low-information, then largely faded into the background, which helped him stay uncontroversial and made it harder to read or leverage him for misdirection.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I played solidly and stayed uncontroversial, which helped keep suspicion away from both me and the likely power roles while supporting generally good team selections. I could improve by being more vocal about structured reasoning for or against certain teams, so my reads influence the table more instead of mostly following others’ leads.

player_observations.Alice: She projected a very steady, trustworthy presence and leaned into consistent team choices, which made her a natural hub for team-building and a tempting assassin target.
player_observations.Bob: He was active and assertive in shaping teams, especially around Missions 2–4, which fit well with a power role trying to protect Merlin while still pushing the game in a clear direction.
player_observations.Charlie: He played cautiously but with just enough quiet influence on team compositions to steer things the right way without drawing too much attention, which makes sense now that we know he was Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: She stayed relatively under the radar and didn’t push hard narratives, which made it harder to pin her as evil but also meant she wasn’t a central force in team debates.
player_observations.Eve: She blended in well early by going on the first mission and keeping it clean, then introduced just enough doubt on the later mission to cause a fail without overexposing herself as a likely evil.
